trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised control trial assessing outcomes of two service models providing nutritional support to older people presenting to the Emergency Department
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In older patients presenting to the Emergency Department, do those who receive a nutrition intervention achieve a better nutritional status than those who receive standard care only? A comparison of two service models.

conditions.healthcondition: Nutritional Status of Older people presenting to Emergency Department

interventions.interventions: Individualised nutritional care from a dietitian, beginning on the day of presentation to Emergency Department, with monthly follow-up over the phone for a three month period.
interventions.comparator: Usual care as per Community Hospital Interface Program (CHIP) nursing staff and community support

primaryOutcome.outcome: Weight assessed using bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) scales
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months

primaryOutcome.outcome: Nutritional Status assessed via Subjective Global Assessment (SGA) and Patient Generated Subjective Global Assessment (PGSGA)
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months

primaryOutcome.outcome: Protein and Energy Intake assessed using 24 hour recall entered into the Food Works (Registered Trademark) software program
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of Life assessed by the EuroQol 5 dimension questionnaire (EQ-5D)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months
Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months
Assessed on Baseline and again after 3 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Incidence of falls and fractures resulting from falls as reported by patient
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: incidence of falls assessed for 6 months immediately prior to baseline, and from baseline for 3 months

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Hospital and Emergency Department admissions assessed through Hospital Information Management Services
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Over 3 months from date of randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Length of stay assessed through Hospital Information Management Services
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Over 3 months from date of randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: incidence of pressure ulcers assessed through Hospital Information Management Services
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Over 3 months from date of randomisation

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Death assessed through Hospital Information Management Services
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Over 3 months from date of randomisation

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: a) admitted to Emergency Department b) aged 60 years or over c) assessed at malnutrition risk using the Malnutrition Screening Tool (MST)
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: a) unable to receive informed consent b) Triage Category 1 (highest priority) c) already receiving dietetic care d) admitted from a health care facility (including nursing home)

trial_design.concealment: Randomised sequence, randomly generated numbers sealed in sequentially numbered opaque envelopes

fundingsource.fundingname: Queensland Health - Health practitioner research scheme
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Allied Health Clinincal education and Training unit Queensland Health PO Box 48 , Brisbane 4000

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
The study aimed to help inform how best to deliver nutrition services to older adults identified at risk of malnutrition, through the provision of frequent, individual nutrition support by a dietitian from the Emergency Department, compared with the provision of the current service to community-dwelling older adults identified as at risk of malnutrition.
This investigation aims to assess the impact of the service provided on the nutritional status and other outcomes including frail mechanical falls, hospital admission and quality of life.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Vivanti A, Isenring E, Baumann, Powrie, D, O'Neill M, Clark D, Courtice S, Campbell K, Ferguson M. Emergency department malnutrition screening and support model improves outcomes in a pilot Randomised Controlled Trial. Emergency Medicine Journal. 2015; 32:180-183.
